column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=5 .
#Text=Discussion
#Text=5.1 .
#Text=Strengths and Limitations of the Framework
#Text=Timeseries products present different temporal scales components , such as seasonal variations , long-term and short-term fluctuations .
#Text=Their high temporal resolution offers the opportunity to define time profiles of vegetation dynamics .

#Text=Although many methods have been developed to explore vegetation dynamics at a global or regional scale , quantitative methods that could automatically address where , when and how vegetation change are still lacking .
#Text=Trajectory-based change detection is an inevitable choice to do this work by constructing a ‘ curve ’ or profile of full temporal records for each pixel .
#Text=Nowadays , the method has been successfully applied in forest-related change analyses , land use classification , and cropland variations .
#Text=The framework we proposed in our study is a trajectory-based change detection method .
#Text=It has several desirable properties compared with other fashionable methods .

#Text=Firstly , unlike the widely used trend analyses which hypothesize that ecosystems/vegetation always change linearly in a direction , our framework could detect the non-linear change patterns in vegetation .
#Text=All patterns in the framework can be interpreted from unambiguous biophysical standpoints .
#Text=Secondly , unlike DBEST and BFAST , our framework automatically generalizes processes of vegetation gradual changes into different patterns without setting any parameters .
#Text=Furthermore , the patterns between different pixels or areas could be compared easily .

#Text=Although DBEST and BFAST could also track vegetation gradual change by a piecewise linear model on the pixel scale , the number of breakpoints must be set by users when the method was extended to the regional scale .

#Text=For example , de Jong detected the short-term greening or browning periods within long-term timeseries by dividing the trend component in BFAST into four segments which were separated by three breakpoints .
#Text=Then , the duration of the significant greening and browning segments , the magnitude of change in NDVI , and the abrupt changes could be compared between pixels subsequently .
#Text=Lastly , trajectory-based change detection only functions when the process of vegetation change matches well with the hypothesized trajectory .
#Text=Temporal trajectories of vegetation changes in different pixels may be different .
#Text=Therefore , many mathematical models are needed to fit the trajectories .
#Text=However , just a logistic model is used to simulate all the non-linear monotonic patterns in our framework .
#Text=Drawbacks of our framework are obvious .
#Text=Firstly , only four monotonic patterns and eight types are presented .
#Text=All the patterns are associated with only one disturbance event within the timescales of the observation period (
#Text=Figure 4
#Text=) .
#Text=Generally , changes in vegetation are complicated and difficult to be generalized by a single function .

#Text=Therefore , patterns that are composed of the general categories in our framework , or patterns that vegetation gradual changes were stalled or reverse by abrupt events , were not discussed in this study .
#Text=New models that could detect both the monotonic and the non-monotonic patterns are needed to be induced in future .
#Text=Secondly , the smoothed treatment implemented on the NDVI timeseries makes the framework unsuitable to detect subtle changes or abrupt changes .
#Text=However , it makes the framework unspecific to the MODIS timeseries products which do not suffer from the problem of data discontinuity .

#Text=The data discontinuities which may be caused by changes in different sensors , orbital drift in the satellite overpass times , variations in sun-sensor-viewer geometry or differences in the atmospheric conditions ( i. e. , water vapour content , aerosols ) are common in other timeseries products , such as datasets from AVHRR , Landsat and VEGETATION .
